greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the binary representation of n converted to yranib.
comment: If n = Sum_{i=0..k} b_i*2^i, b_i = 0 or 1, b_k = 1, then a(n) = y(k) - Sum_{i=0..k-1} b_i*y(i), where y(j) = A004094(j) = 2^j written backwards in base 10.

If the 2^14 terms from a(16384) to a(32767) were to be considered a packet [call it #1], then the terms from a(32768) to a(49151) [call it #2] are #1 + 38362. #3 = #2 - 48361 (note that 48361 is the reverse of 16384). #4 = #3 + 25194. These successive displacements
-38362, -48361,   71528, -48361, ...) fully describe the future of the sequence. Can we predict the values of the displacements from first principles? - _Hans Havermann_, Feb 24 2021
reference: Eric Angelini, Posting to Math Fun Mailing List, Feb 18 2021
link: Jinyuan Wang, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
mathematica: {0}~Join~Array[Fold[Subtract, Reverse@ IntegerReverse[2^(-1 + Position[Reverse@ IntegerDigits[#, 2], 1][[All, 1]] )]] &, 69] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Feb 25 2021 *)
program: /* Get decimal value of yranib representation of n written in binary (i.e., write n in binary, e.g., 9[10] = 1001[2], then read this in the yranib system,where the k-th position from the right has value s*R(2^k) where R=reverse(= decimal value read from right to left) and s = -1 except for the largest k. */ y2d(n)=if(n=binary(n),n[1]*=-1);-sum(k=0,#n-1,n[#n-k]*R(2^k))
xref: See A341708 for the negative terms.
See A341709 for a different version of a yranib sequence.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Feb 18 2021
ext: Further terms from _M. F. Hasler_, Feb 18 2021
